position.marginalia_text: De Republica Romana, post prudentissimos historicos, et scientissimos politicos, pra[e]sertim Polybium, Halicarnasseum, Liuium, et Plutarchum; Sigonium etiam, Manutium, Rosinum, Onuphrium; nec non Machiauellum, Zasium, Bodinum, et complures alios: tandem consulendum etiam censui Augustinum. Apud quem ha[e]c pra[e]cipuè capita occurrerunt in libris de Ciuitate Dei. Qua definitione constet, populi, et reipublica[e] nuncupationem rectè sibi, non solùm Romanos, sed etiam regna alia vendicare. l. 19. c. 24. An secundùm definitiones Scipionis, qua[e] in dialogo Ciceronis sunt, vnq[uam] fuerit Romana respublica. L. eod. c. 21. Si res publica, res populi; nunq[uam] fuit Romana resp. Qua[e] sententia[e] fuerit Ciceronis de Romana Republica. l. 2. c. 26. Qua[e] de moribus Romanorum, aut metu compressis, aut securitate resolutis, Sallustij probat historia. l. eod. c. 18. De vitijs Romanorum, quos patria[e] non correxit euersio. l. 1. c. 33. Quibus vitiorum gradibus aucta sit in Romanis cupido regnandi. l. eod. c. 31. Quanta euersione publica[e] disciplina[e], Romani dijs suis placandis sacrauerint obscoena ludoru[m]. l. 2. c. 27. Debuisse intelligere Romanos, quòd dij eorum, qui se turpibus ludis coli expetebant, indigni essent honore diuino. L. eod. c. 13. Quòd si Dijs vlla esset cura Justitia[e], ab eis Romani accipere debuerint pra[e]cepta viuendi potiùs, quàm Leges ab alijs hominibus mutuare. l. eod. c. 16. De mercede temporali, quam Deus reddidit bonis moribus Romanorum. l. 5. c. 15. Causam Romani imperij, omniumque regnorum, nec fortuitam esse, nec in stellaru[m] positione consistere. [book 5] c. 1. Quibus moribus antiqui Romani merueru[n]t, vt Deus verus, quamuis non illum colerent, eorum augeret imperium. c. 12. Romanum regnum à Deo esse dispositum; a quo est omnis potestas, et cuius prouidentia reguntur vniuersa. c. 21. (Insigne caput, et eximiè notabile. Quando voluit, et quantu[m] voluit, Romanis regnu[m] dedit, qui dedit Assyrijs, vel Persis. Sic etiam hominibus, qui Mario, ipse Ca[e]sari: qui Augusto, ipse Neroni: qui Vespasianis, suauissimis Impp. ipse Domitiano crudelissimo. Qui Constantino Christiano, ipse apostata[e] Juliano. Etsi occultis causis, nunquid iniustis?) Quo fructu Romani bella gesserint, et quantum his, quos vicêre, contulerint. L. eod. c. 17. De vario vtruysq[ue] regni Hebra[e]orum statu, donec ambo populi in captiuitatem diuerso tempore ducerentur, reuocato postèa Juda in regnum suum: quod nouissimè in Romanorum transijt potestatem. l. 17. c. 23. Tandem enim Juda[e]i, à Pompeio primùm expugnati, Romanorum erant tributarij: eorumque res deinceps administrata[e] per pra[e]sides Syria[e], et Procuratores Juda[e]a[e], à Romanis missos. Non desunt alia qua[e]dam in illis polychrestis libris consentanea capita: sed ha[e]c mihi potissimùm uidebantur excerpenda: alia aliàs obseruaui. Cumque apud Sigonium, et ca[e]teros polyhistores id genus, nobilissimas mundi Respublicas, Romanorum, Atheniensium, Laceda[e]moniorum, Hebra[e]orum legissem: memini, lectum postmodò Augustinum, non modò Romanorum, sed etiam Gra[e]corum, et Hebra[e]orum statibus, rebusq[ue] gestis mirificam lucem affudisse: pra[e]sertim Hebra[e]orum. Valdeq[ue] placuit, in illis, alijsq[ue] maximis mundi imperijs, atq[ue] regnis, acutissimi Doctoris iudicium. Nec vnq[uam] poenitebit, ad tot excellentes, celeberrimasq[ue] Respublicas, pra[e]sertim Aristotelis, Platonis, Xenophontis, Plutarchi, Ciceronis, quantum exstat; Contareni etiam, Mori, Patritij, Bodini, postremò Althusij, et nescio quot recentium politicorum; tandem etiam Augustini Rempublicam aggregasse, id est, Ciuitatem Dei. Romani, Legum, Armorumq[ue] maximi professores. Vndè diligentissima in illorum iam tum leges, et arma, acerrimaq[ue] est opus inquisitione. De iuris Principijs, et Legum Romanarum infinita varietate nemo peritiùs, aut profundiùs, quàm C. Tacitus l. 3. Annalium. Ipsa[e] Leges apud Grae[co]s, Latinosq[ue] historicos; Ciceronem de Legibus, in Topicis, in Orationib. Fragmenta XII. Tabularu[m], a Ra[e]uardo, Gothofredo, alijsq[ue] tam iureconsultis, quàm philologis collecta: singulares scriptores de antiquis ante Justinianum Legibus, Pomp. La[e]tum, Zasium, Manutium, Sigonium, Rosinum, Hotomanum, Prateium, et tales fortassè nonnullos. Armorum non noui acriores auctores, quàm Vegetium, Frontinum, Machiauellum, Bellaium; de militia Romana tot nominatim scriptores, Patritium, Sigonium, Rosinum, Lipsium, alios; Ramum de militia Ca[e]saris, et de moribus veterum Gallorum; nouissimè Ranzouium, pugna[e] terrestri, et nauali vtilem. Nusq[uam] autem, Romani status hypothesis viuidiùs descripta; aut artes senatoria[e], id est, veteratoria[e] profundiùs detecta[e], totiusq[ue] Reipublica[e] arcana intimiùs reclusa, quàm duabus regis Mithridatis sagacissimis informationibus, vna ad regem Arsacem epistola; altera ad milites Oratione. Qua[e] exstat vtraq[ue] clarissimis mandata historijs: ha[e]c apud Justinum; illa apud Sallustium. Cuiusmodi multa si penitùs percalluissent nostri politici discursores, haud dubiè varias haberemus in ciuili, militariq[ue] genere obseruationes, disquisitiones, cautelas, praxes multò peritiores, ac solertiores, quàm adhuc exstant. Quanq[uam] mea summa animaduersio est, non tam historicis Exemplis defecisse probatissimos scriptores, quàm politicis pra[e]ceptis, ipsisq[ue] iudicij fundamentis. Certè verisq[ue] admodùm est opus, et solidis scientia[e] principijs; et virtutis excellentibus historijs. Quorum illis ferè Gra[e]ci; his Romani pra[e]stiterunt.

marginalia.translation: On the Roman Republic, after [reading] the most judicious historians and most knowledgeable politicians, especially Polybius, Dionysius of Halicarnassus, Livy and Plutarch, one should also consult Sigonius, Manutius, Rosinus, Onuphrius [Panvinius], as well as Machiavelli, Zasius, Bodin, and a great many others. Finally I believed also Augustine should be consulted. And in his City of God the following chapters in particular came to the attention: What is the definition which must be given of a ‘people’ and a ‘commonwealth’ in order to show that these titles may be claimed not only by the Roman but by other kingdoms also: bk. 19, ch. 24; Whether there ever was a Roman commonwealth answering to the definitions proposed by Scipio in Cicero’s dialogue: the same bk., ch. 21; if the commonwealth were the property of the people, there never was a Roman commonwealth. Cicero’s opinion of the Roman commonwealth: bk. 2, ch. 21. What Sallust’s History reveals of the morals of the Roman people both when oppressed by fear and at ease in security: the same bk., ch. 18. Of the vices of the Romans, which were not corrected by the fall of their fatherland: bk. 1, ch. 33. By what degrees of vice the desire for rule increased among the Romans: the same bk., ch. 31. That the obscenity of the games celebrated to propitiate the Roman gods did much to undermine public discipline: bk. 2, ch. 27. That the Romans should have known that gods who desired to be worshipped with disgraceful plays were unworthy of divine honours: the same bk., ch. 13. That if the gods had possessed any regard for justice, the Romans would have received precepts of life from them, rather than having to borrow them from other men: the same bk., ch. 16. Of the temporal reward which God granted to the good morals of the Romans: bk. 5, ch. 15. That the cause of the Roman empire, and of all kingdoms, is not mere chance; nor does it consist in the position of the starts: bk. [5], ch. 1. By what merits the ancient Romans deserved that the true God should enlarge their empire even though they did not worship Him: ch. 12. That the Roman realm was established by God, from Whom all power comes, and by Whose providence all things are ruled: ch. 21. (A remarkable, extraordinarily noteworthy chapter. He gave a kingdom to the Romans when it pleased Him and to the extent that it pleased Him. He also gave one to the Assyrians, and then again to the Persians. So also in the case of individual men: He Who gave it to the Vespasii, father and son, the gentlest of emperors, also gave it to Domitian, the cruellest. He Who gave it to the Christian Constantine, also gave it to the apostate Julian. Though the causes are hidden, are they unjust?) For what profit the Romans waged wars, and what benefits they conferred upon those whom they conquered: the same bk., ch. 17. Of the varying fortunes of each of the Hebrew kingdoms, until the people of both were at different times led away captive; Judah being afterwards restored to its kingdom, which eventually passed into the power of the Romans: bk. 17, ch. 23. For at last the Jews, first defeated by Pompey, were tributaries of the Romans, and their affairs were governed by the governors of Syria and the procurators of Judea, who were sent by the Romans. And there are several more fitting chapters in these highly useful books, but I thought these in particular should be excerpted. Other chapters I have noted elsewhere. After I had read in Sigonius, and other polyhistors of this class, about the noblest commonwealths in the world, of the Romans, Athenians, Spartans and Israelites, I remember that a subsequent reading of Augustine shed a remarkably great light on the constitutions and achievements of not only the Romans, but also the Greeks and the Hebrews, especially the Hebrews. I greatly liked the extremely perceptive judgement of this Doctor [of the Church] about these and other great empires and kingdoms of the world. One will never regret in addition to so many outstanding and famous Republics, especially those of Aristotle, Plato, Xenophon, Plutarch, Cicero –so far as remains –, also of Contarini, More, Patrizzi, Bodin, and finally, Althusius, and an indefinite number of more recent political theorists, at last to have included also Augustine’s Republic, that is, the 'City of God'. The Romans are the greatest experts in laws and military action. Therefore one needs an extremely careful and most penetrating investigation into their laws and military exploits already at that time. Noone is more competent or thorough about the principles of justice and the endless diversity of the laws of the Romans than Cornelius Tacitus in bk. 3 of his 'Annals'. The laws by themselves in the Greek and Roman historians: Cicero 'De legibus'; in his 'Topica'; in his Speeches; the fragments of the 12 Tables, collected by Raevardus, Gothofredus, and other jurists as well as philologists. Excellent authors about the ancient laws before Justinian are Pomponius Laetus, Zasius, Manutius, Sigonius, Rosinus, Hotman, Prateius, and possibly several others. About military actions I do not know more astute authors than Vegetius, Frontinus, Machiavelli, Bellaius; about the Roman military I know so many by name: Patrizzi, Sigonius, Rosinus, Lipsius and others; Ramus about Caesar’s military and about the customs of the ancient Gauls; most recently Ranzovius, who is useful for the battle on land and at sea. Yet the subject of the Roman state is nowhere nowhere described livelier, or the senatorial, that is experienced, skills more thoroughly uncovered, and the mysteries of the entire commonwealth more profoundly revealed, than in two extremely perceptive initiatives of king Mithridates, the one a letter to king Arsaces, the other a speech to his soldiers. And what is preserved of both is handed over by extremely bright historians: the latter in Justin, the former in Sallust. If our political theorists would be fully versed in the many materials of this sort, we would undoubtedly have had numerous much more expert and clever observations, investigations, precautions and practices in the field of civil and military affairs. And yet my final observation is that the most esteemed writers do not run short of historical examples, but of political rules and the very foundations of judgment. There is really a need for both true and firm principles of knowledge and excellent stories of virtue. And of these the Greeks were just about the best in the former, the Romans in the latter.
